form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Bennet (for himself and Mr. Portman) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

form.official-title: To create a consistent framework to expedite the recruitment of highly qualified personnel who perform information technology, cybersecurity, and cyber-related functions to enhance cybersecurity across the Federal Government.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act.

paragraph.text: The term appropriate congressional committees means—

subparagraph.text: the Committee on Armed Services of the Senate;
the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate;
the Committee on Armed Services in the House of Representatives;
the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives; and
the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform of House of Representatives.

paragraph.text: The term Director means the Director of the Office of Personnel Management.
The term roles has the meaning given the term in the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education's Cybersecurity Workforce Framework.

subsection.text: The head of each Federal agency shall—

paragraph.text: identify all positions within the agency that require the performance of information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related functions; and
assign the corresponding employment code, which shall be added to the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education’s National Cybersecurity Workforce Framework, in accordance with subsection (b).

subparagraph.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Commerce, acting through the National Institute of Standards and Technology, shall update the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education's Cybersecurity Workforce Framework to include a corresponding coding structure.

Not later than 9 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Director, in coordination with the Director of National Intelligence, shall establish procedures to implement the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education’s coding structure to identify all Federal civilian positions that require the performance of information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related functions.

Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Defense shall establish procedures to implement the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education’s coding structure to identify all Federal non-civilian positions that require the performance of information technology, cybersecurity or other cyber-related functions.

subparagraph.header: Baseline assessment of existing cybersecurity workforce
subparagraph.text: Not later than 3 months after the date on which the procedures are developed under subparagraphs (B) and (C), respectively, the head of each Federal agency shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees of jurisdiction a report that identifies—

clause.text: the percentage of personnel with information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related job functions who currently hold the appropriate industry-recognized certifications as identified in the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education’s Cybersecurity Workforce Framework;
the level of preparedness of other civilian and non-civilian cyber personnel without existing credentials to pass certification exams; and
a strategy for mitigating any gaps identified in clause (i) or (ii) with the appropriate training and certification for existing personnel.

subparagraph.text: Not later than 3 months after the date on which the procedures are developed under subparagraphs (B) and (C), respectively, the head of each Federal agency shall establish procedures—

clause.text: to identify all encumbered and vacant positions with information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related functions (as defined in the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education's coding structure); and
to assign the appropriate employment code to each such position, using agreed standards and definitions.

paragraph.text: Not later than 1 year after the date after the procedures are established under paragraph (1)(E), the head of each Federal agency shall complete assignment of the appropriate employment code to each position within the agency with information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related functions.

subsection.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Director shall submit a progress report on the implementation of this section to the appropriate congressional committees.

section.header: Identification of cyber-related roles of critical need

subsection.text: Beginning not later than 1 year after the date on which the employment codes are assigned to employees pursuant to section 3(b)(2), and annually through 2022, the head of each Federal agency, in consultation with the Director and the Secretary of Homeland Security, shall—

paragraph.text: identify information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related roles of critical need in the agency’s workforce; and
submit a report to the Director that—

subparagraph.text: describes the information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related roles identified under paragraph (1); and

subsection.text: The Director shall provide Federal agencies with timely guidance for identifying information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related roles of critical need, including—

paragraph.text: current information technology, cybersecurity, and other cyber-related roles with acute skill shortages; and
information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related roles with emerging skill shortages.

subsection.text: Not later than 2 years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, shall—

paragraph.text: identify critical needs for information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related workforce across all Federal agencies; and
submit a progress report on the implementation of this section to the appropriate congressional committees.

section.text: The Comptroller General of the United States shall—

paragraph.text: analyze and monitor the implementation of sections 3 and 4; and
not later than 3 years after the date of the enactment of this Act, submit a report to the appropriate congressional committees that describes the status of such implementation.
